headline: M&S supplier back to pen and paper after cyber attack - BBC News
context: One of Marks & Spencer's biggest suppliers has resorted to using pen and paper for orders as the disruption from the cyber attack on the retailer continues.
The boss of Greencore, which supplies sandwiches, rolls and wraps, says it has also ramped up deliveries by a fifth to make sure there is more than enough food for the bank holiday weekend.

annotations.paragraph: M&S has been unable to offer online orders for clothing and homewares for over a week, and some stores have seen empty shelves as food deliveries have also been disrupted.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific details about the impact of the cyber attack on M&S operations.

annotations.paragraph: Two M&S workers told the BBC they were concerned about pay because they were unable to clock in and out of work and could not access staff apps.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers insight into the personal impact on M&S employees due to the cyber attack.

annotations.paragraph: In a glimpse into the behind-the-scenes situation at M&S, Greencore chief executive Dalton Philips said: "In the absence of having all the systems speaking to each other, you revert to how it was 25 years ago."
annotations.reason: This quote provides direct commentary on the operational challenges faced by M&S due to the cyber attack.

annotations.paragraph: That means back to "pen and paper", he said.
annotations.reason: This sentence reiterates the main point about reverting to manual processes.

annotations.paragraph: Greencore has also been putting on additional shifts at its dedicated M&S factory in Northampton, putting more lorries on the road, and is sending more food to stores than they did over Christmas.
annotations.reason: This paragraph details the measures taken by Greencore to mitigate the impact of the cyber attack.

annotations.paragraph: "They're a massive customer for us and we're trying to flood them with products to help them," said Mr Philips.
annotations.reason: This quote provides direct commentary from a supplier about their response to the cyber attack.

annotations.paragraph: "There are times when you do need to revert to manual systems in any business... but look, it works well.
annotations.reason: This quote explains the necessity and effectiveness of reverting to manual systems due to the cyber attack.

annotations.paragraph: "With the challenges of the system we don't have intricate forecasting that we would have previously had, so we're just making sure that they've got everything they need and some more."
annotations.reason: This provides insight into the operational challenges faced due to the cyber attack.

annotations.paragraph: George, not his real name, works at an M&S in Wales, and said it has been "a nightmare".
annotations.reason: This quote adds a personal perspective on the impact of the cyber attack.

annotations.paragraph: "We have been told pay will be given through a separate payment system. However, we have not been told whether the pay will be correct."
annotations.reason: This highlights an issue related to employee payment systems affected by the cyber attack.

annotations.paragraph: "Additionally, there have been back-and-forth instructions, which have changed hourly. For example: remove gift cards from shop floor, put them back (when working)."
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific examples of the operational disruptions caused by the cyber attack.

annotations.paragraph: Jeannette Pellen, 76, in Doncaster who retired from her role as an M&S customer assistant in a Scunthorpe store at the end of April, said they had been unable to clock in and out of work as a result of the attack.
annotations.reason: This paragraph gives a personal account of the impact of the cyber attack on M&S employees.

annotations.paragraph: "There is no way of receiving advice via managers or the outsourced HR," she told the BBC.
annotations.reason: This quote highlights communication issues faced by employees due to the cyber attack.

annotations.paragraph: M&S has reassured staff that they will be paid for all contracted hours as usual.

annotations.paragraph: As a former chief executive of the supermarket chain Morrisons, Mr Philips knows only too well the pressure M&S bosses are under.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is a tangential comment about a former executive's perspective, not directly related to the cyber attack.

annotations.paragraph: "They will be literally working 24/7. You've got to work your way through it. Whenever I've spoken to the team this week, it's been really impressive how calm and focused they are.

annotations.paragraph: "I think if you work in retail, you know people are often the most on their game and motivated at those periods of intense pressure."

annotations.paragraph: M&S hasn't released details on how its systems have been affected, saying only that some have been temporarily taken offline leading to pockets of limited availability in stores.
